Australians do want us to do better; to put their interests before our own; to do the right thing when no-one is looking; to give our opponents credit when they deserve it and, when they don't, confront the contention and not the person; and to do our best to answer questions, perhaps even in this place, maybe experiment with words like, 'I don't know, but I will find out and get back to you,' and admit mistakes when we make them. I'll make one: the coalition didn't introduce an integrity commission bill, and we should have. Australians also want us to consider this before we go to sleep every night, to answer a simple question, 'Am I proud of what I did today?'

I support the introduction of the National Anti-Corruption Commission, or NACC, but we must get the balance right. It is tempting to view this debate as just about us. The Prime Minister, ministers, 76 senators and 151 members of this place will be subject to the NACC, as we should be. But it should not be forgotten that the jurisdiction will also cover the lives of over 7,000 members of the Australian Federal Police, who keep us safe; 84,000 members of the Australian Defence Force, who secure our nation and put their lives on the line; and over 248,000 Australian public servants, who serve the nation, as well as hundreds of thousands of contractors, subcontractors and anyone exercising a power under the Commonwealth. They are relying upon us to get the detail right, and it is our belief that further safeguards will make the NACC more effective and fairer, because at the end of this debate the NACC must be an institution that enhances our democracy. I believe that it has the potential to do that, but not without risk.

I was one of 12 members of the joint select committee that was tasked with reviewing the bill. I thank the chair, Senator White, and the deputy chair, who is kindly sitting in the chamber, the member for Indi, as well as the other members of the committee. And it's worth noting that a huge percentage were new members from the class of 2022, and I think the committee was better for it. I also thank the secretariat, who worked so hard on a tight deadline, and each person and organisation who provided a submission and/or appeared online or in person. I particularly thank my coalition colleagues, Senator Claire Chandler, Senator Paul Scarr and the member for Wide Bay, Llew O'Brien. We all bring our personal experiences, and the member for Wide Bay has had personal experiences, in a very positive way—he did the right thing—of a state corruption commission.

Before I detail additional safeguards that this parliament should consider, I welcome the amendments announced today by the Attorney-General, including broader protections for journalists, advising a person who has been cleared of an investigation of the outcome, and requiring warrant sign-off by a Superior Court judge. I can understand the political pointscoring about politicising the AAT. We would do the same. But the key point there wasn't the political biases of the AAT members; it was about tenure. Judges are appointed for life. So, they don't have to go selling their wares for another job. AAT members have five- or seven-year appointments, so one day they have to go looking for another job—and I would rather they don't know that the Prime Minister's phone was tapped. With a judge, at least you know they can retire in peace with that secret going to the grave.

Some of the other improvements include beefing up the power of the inspector. We will talk a lot about the role of the commissioner, but the inspector is really the person who watches the watcher, and it's a very important part of this institution. But I do wonder whether, if we had more time, we could have made it even better. I don't say that with any irony, noting the mistake that I admitted our side made. But it would have been nice to have considered this further. Next to me are the two bills—the bill, the consequential bill and then the explanatory memorandum. The bill is 222 pages long. The consequential bill is 87 pages and the explanatory memorandum a whopping 358 pages. It's a credit to all those who drafted it. It's very well written. But it's a combined total of 667 pages.

During the 43 days of the committee's inquiry, the window for public submissions spanned a mere nine days, during which a total of 140 submissions were made. The member for Indi would be pleased to know that my office added that up and it was 1,340 pages that we had to flick through—and we did; we did the work. The submissions were received from across Australia. The public consultation process sought to allow anyone to have their voices heard, from experts, stakeholders, former and current commissioners, academics, government departments, community groups, policing personnel—a wide variety of experience. I do wish we had more time to hear from them.

Yet, in spite of all of this, the committee and the secretariat worked diligently and cooperatively to do our job in the time given. I am new, as many of the committee members are, but I saw in that committee this parliament at its best, and I think that's the sort of start this commission should have.

So before I expand on some of the further safeguards, let me say something about the person who will be charged with running this institution, the commissioner. No matter what further safeguards we include by amendment or otherwise, the person the government ultimately appoints, or the person future governments ultimately appoint, will have enormous capacity to do good or harm. Senator Shoebridge, who was on the committee, put this question to many of the witnesses: 'When drafting this bill, should we assume the best Attorney-General or the worst?'—and he qualified it by saying this Attorney-General is not the worst! The answer, of course, is that, when drafting legislation like this, you should assume the worst. That is prudent.

The same goes for the commissioner. This person will not possess superhuman powers of integrity or ethics. They will be human. They will have biases, prejudices, things they are competent at and things they are not. The member for Indi saw some eminent retired judges struggling with their internet log-ons and asking what Twitter was. That's fine—no criticism. But we're not all experts at everything. If this commission is to stand the test of time, every now and again we will have a bad commissioner, and the parliament must proceed with eyes wide open to that.

There are many potential amendments and key terms, and probably one of the most contested is the public-hearing test, so I'd like to focus on that. The exceptional-circumstances test is contentious. I submit that it is not ambiguous or uncertain, but I do admit it is strict. I support a strict public hearing test for the following reason: it would be unfair to apply court-like transparency without court-like rules of evidence. Many on the crossbench quite fairly put the argument that's often put for open courts, and I'm a big believer in open justice, but I don't think those arguments fairly apply to this institution. It's not a court, and that matters. It is an arm of the executive, a very powerful one that, unlike courts, strips people of almost all of the rights that are afforded to them in a court.

We heard from bodies like the Centre for Public Integrity, the Accountability Round Table, Transparency International, the Australia Institute and the Human Rights Law Centre on public hearings. They are running hot on this issue, and I understand the passion behind that. But I want to put this question to them: if public hearings are so vital to a body like this, why don't you ever stand up and advocate for the rights that are afforded in courts to also apply here? Surely if this condition for public hearings is so essential then that is a compromise worth accepting, a price worth paying and a simple nod to fairness. But they never do.

Some submissions raised the spectre of excessive litigation in relation to the exceptional-circumstances test. Again, a lot of those same bodies made that argument in their written submissions, but I note it has gone missing from their media releases lately. These submissions are mostly from those groups, and a person who I think very highly of, a fellow Victorian bar member, Ms Fiona McLeod AO SC, was quoted as saying it's 'a lawyer's picnic waiting to happen'. Now it is clearly evident from the Victorian test—this test comes from the Victorian IBAC Act, and I'm a Victorian—that this claim is speculative and is not reflected in the facts. Of the 10 public hearings held by the IBAC from 2014-15 through to 2021-22, there has only been one case that has dealt with it substantively; it's R & M v IBAC, and it considered that test.

Some submissions raised concerns about the likely reduced number of public hearings that will be held by the NACC due to the test, and we do agree that such a test will result in fewer public hearings. That's a fact. But the submissions exaggerated that percentage. You can choose to show the total number of hearings, and, if you show the total number of hearings, there's quite a disparity between Victoria and New South Wales. In fact, some have the New South Wales number being nine times as great. But we submit that a better way is to compare the hearing days, because some matters, as quickly as they come onto the desk of the commissioner, are flicked off again. So, for serious inquiries and investigations, measuring the days that are held publicly or privately is a more useful measure.

Let's compare ICAC and IBAC, New South Wales and Victoria. The percentage of hearing days that were public in New South Wales, in the same period that the IBAC existed, was 52.6. In that same period for Victoria it was 27.8. So no-one's pretending that it's more than New South Wales; clearly it's less. But it's not manifestly less to the point of being only one-ninth as much, and 27.8 per cent of hearing days is still a significant percentage. This test doesn't kill public hearings. It just makes it harder. We submit that that is appropriate, especially for a Commonwealth integrity commission. The Commonwealth has powers and responsibilities that the state commissions don't have, and that really matters.

A major concern would be any compromise to national security, and the prospect of future criminal trials being thwarted. And, we submit, the shame that comes on an individual and their families in a public hearing has to be a key consideration. Again, I know that those who are advocating for the test still require that to be a consideration, and they've put it in different ways. I'd like to reference some evidence given by Dr Davis-McCabe, from the Australian Psychological Society. I thought this was persuasive:
With the ADF members, we see high rates of PTSD and trauma in that group … so they might be a group that is at higher risk and likely to have more severe mental health issues.
Dr Davis-McCabe continued:

Just on the identity: someone's job and position and profession is core to their identity, and, when that identity is attacked, it attacks the core of that person, and it's that attack that leads to the decline in mental health because then the person is left asking: 'Who am I? What is my purpose? What is my role?' When it's within a public hearing, I think that there is a lot of shame around that, and that kind of public hearing, or social media or media, sort of amplifies that shame.

So let's be very clear: more public hearings equals greater damage to individuals—particularly those in our national security agencies and Defence—and increases the risk of suicide. I don't think that's a risk worth taking. It's not fair. So the coalition supports the retention of the test with further safeguards, and I won't go through those now. I support the amendment to get rid of 8(1)(e). That was an inappropriate catch-all expansion which doesn't appear in any other state corruption commission, and it was appropriate that that went.

Finally, bipartisanship is essential. This can't just be another commission, like the Building and Construction Commission, that comes and goes, depending on who's in government. So bipartisanship is important. I will be voting for this legislation. I commend the bills to the House.

Dr ANANDA-RAJAH (Higgins) (21:22): An Ipsos poll from last year found that, in Australia, doctors are rated as the most trustworthy professionals, followed by scientists and teachers. You all know where this is going: at the bottom of the league table sit politicians, who beat bankers and marketeers for the last spot. It is with some irony then that I have left the most trusted profession for one that is least trusted, and yet the people of Higgins put me here, in part, because I came from that sphere—and that's because integrity matters. Politicians consistently languish at the bottom of the trust index because, for too long, they have gotten away with bad behaviour, with the misuse of power for personal gain.

The misuse of public funds reached a crescendo, and the trust deficit bottomed out, under the last government: sports rorts; car park rorts, also known as the $3 billion Urban Congestion Fund; the Leppington Triangle; regional rorts of $200 million; pool rorts, where a Sydney pool received $10 million from a $150 million fund meant for regional communities; the blind trust; a secret deal with a colleague to garner support for climate action with a cheque of around $2 billion underwritten by the Australian people, without their consent; $444 million to a little-known private foundation called the Great Barrier Reef Authority, which had six staff at the time and, coincidentally, also had links to resources companies; and the disregard of legal caution around robodebt. The whole dirty saga culminated in the ministries miniseries of the former PM, who saw Australia go down a slippery slope from democracy towards autocracy. It always starts small and then it snowballs. The list is by no means exhaustive. I reckon it's the tip of an iceberg. So did my constituents from South Yarra, Windsor, Prahran, Toorak, Armadale, Kooyong, Malvern, Malvern East, Glen Iris, Murrumbeena, Ashburton, Carnegie and Ormond. They all wanted action on integrity. They have had enough of the colour-coded spreadsheets, excuses, doublespeak, smirks and shirking of responsibility. They understand corruption is corrosive and a denial of resources to those in need, like the footy kids in my electorate who need decent sports change rooms or our First Peoples who live in squalor. They understand that nepotism in handouts is bad for the economy because it distorts the free market. Yet it escalated under those opposite because there were no repercussions.

The NACC is the cornerstone of the Albanese government's overarching integrity agenda. It will be a legacy reform, and it is a key election commitment that, unlike the previous government, we are actually delivering. It will have the following features crafted in collaboration, as is the hallmark of our government, with eminent legal and integrity experts. It will have all the powers of a standing royal commission. It will have broad jurisdiction to investigate anyone from a minister down to a staffer, a contractor or an agency. It will be independent, with commissioners held at arm's length from government, overseen by a multipartisan joint parliamentary committee of 12 members as well as an inspector. The commission will be able to initiate investigations under their own steam in response to referrals from anyone. It will have retrospective powers because corruption is like a web; you don't know where or how far it goes until you start digging.

The commission will have public hearings held in exceptional circumstances where it is in the public's interest to do so. I know this has been a point of contention but I draw upon the most trusted profession—doctors—as a benchmark. Investigating misconduct amongst doctors is held behind closed doors, by the regulator, yet trust levels and quality have been maintained. This provision will mitigate against undue reputational harm while protecting the welfare and wellbeing of parliamentarians and their staffers.

Elected representatives have families. We live in communities, and I never want to see anyone here harmed or self-harm. Am I being too precious? I don't think so. Once someone is harmed or dies, it is too late for handwringing. We also want to avoid compromising any future criminal trials. We think we have the settings right here, balancing the benefits of holding public hearings against potential negative impacts. As a doctor, I never want to see suicide or attempted suicide by anyone in this House; I have seen enough of that in my career.

Search or surveillance warrants will be issued by judges, not politicised organisations stacked with cronies. The NACC will be properly funded, providing $90 million more than the former government committed, allowing for approximately 260 staff, and that budget will be reviewed by a joint parliamentary committee every three years to ensure the NACC is appropriately funded. The commission will undertake educational activities as part of its preventative work. It will have safeguards to protect journalists and their sources. For too long the media have been the default anticorruption body in Australia, with influence but no real teeth. Whistleblowers will be dealt with by protecting them from adverse consequences, including criminal offences, but protections will be strengthened through other legislation off the back of the unfulfilled Moss review from many years ago.

I was nothing as a doctor without trust. The same can be said for our leaders. Trust is foundational to the social contract between leaders and the people. Like doctors, we in this House are nothing without it. Fortunately, at this election, the Australian people renovated this House by letting the sunlight in. All I want for Christmas is a NACC with teeth and reach. It will be a gift from the Albanese government to the Australian people under the Christmas tree. But, unlike a lot of presents that are going to be given this year, this one will keep giving for generations to come. I commend this bill to the House.

Mr BATES (Brisbane) (21:29): Throughout the course of our campaign to win Brisbane, we spoke to thousands of people at their doors and over the phone, and two big issues kept coming up: lack of action on climate change; and people just not trusting politicians or our political institutions anymore. This is a crisis of democracy, because if the people within our country do not have faith in the very system that they are governed by, it has lost its legitimacy. While I was doorknocking in the seat of Brisbane during the election campaign, countless members of the community brought up their dissatisfaction with corruption in politics. They were sick of seeing their elected representatives make decisions for corporate and personal benefit instead of for the people they represent. People could just not understand how they themselves were held to account in their own jobs, but somehow politicians were not.

The people of Brisbane and I are glad to see a first step to restoring integrity in politics with this bill establishing an anticorruption commission finally making its way through the House of Representatives. The Greens have argued strongly for a federal anticorruption watchdog for years. I'm incredibly proud of the work done by Senator Larissa Waters in this space. Senator Waters passed a bill establishing a federal ICAC through the Senate back in 2019. The government at the time promised to bring it on for a vote in the House, something which never happened. I'm glad to see, after a record number of Greens and crossbenchers were elected, and now that we've had a change in government, that an anticorruption bill has finally been prioritised.

While this bill is a long overdue step in the right direction, there are still major failings in our democratic system that lead to corrupt outcomes and will continue to erode people's faith in our political system. The most concerning of these for the people of Brisbane—and I would even argue across the country more broadly—is the influence of money in politics. The sentiment in the community, which is justified, is that money talks. If, for example, I'm a large corporation—be it BHP, Woolworths or Santos—and I donate large sums of money to political parties, I'm going to expect something in return. These donations are an investment, more than anything else. I call them an investment because they almost always guarantee a return.

Perhaps the most prevalent and obvious of these are donations from the fossil fuel industry. That's why fossil fuel companies in this country pay some of the lowest royalties in the world—it's because they have donated for that privilege. The major parties pocketed $14.6 million in donations during the last financial year from corporations, and that doesn't include the millions in undisclosed dark money our weak donation laws don't capture. Some of these serial donors include the fossil fuel, gambling and alcohol industries, the private health sector, banks and the big four consultancy firms. Is it a coincidence that these industries are some of the most poorly regulated and are awarded some of the most valuable government contracts? Why would corporations and billionaires donate money to political parties if it were not to buy an outcome? I can assure you they are not making these donations out of the goodness and generosity of their own hearts. It's a common career path, as well, for a member in the House of Representatives or the Senate to depart politics and find themselves working for the very industry that they were tasked with regulating. Australians have, sadly, become accustomed to this revolving-door style of politics, and our democracy is undermined as a result.

Restoring faith in politicians will require a lot more than just this one bill. A real representative democracy would be one which is entirely free of corporate influence and dirty donations. We want to see public NACC hearings in more than just extraordinary circumstances; we want a genuinely independent oversight committee. This bill is not perfect, but it is a first step. We need even greater public oversight of politicians and a ban on corporate donations, to end the revolving door of politician to lobbyist and to truly restore faith in our democracy.

Mr NEUMANN (Blair) (21:33): I'm pleased to speak on the National Anti-Corruption Commission Bill 2022 and the National Anti-Corruption Commission (Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2022. Prior to the election, Labor made a commitment to return integrity, honesty and accountability to government and to restore people's trust in politics and our public institutions, after years of governmental action falling short of the expectations of the public, perpetrated and perpetuated by the Morrison government. Let's not forget the former Prime Minister first promised a Commonwealth integrity commission in December 2018, and he released an exposure draft in November 2020. After more than three years of delay and obfuscation, on the eve of the election this year, the former government completely abandoned any pretence that they ever intended to deliver a national anticorruption commission. Indeed, the Morrison government didn't even bring the legislation before the parliament. I recall multiple occasions when the then Prime Minister was challenged to bring the bill. He even tabled a bill but never actually introduced it—an extraordinary performance!

Yet the need for a national integrity body couldn't have been more clear after nearly a decade of waste under the coalition. They had sports rorts, dubious land deals and colour coded spread sheets for grants. It seemed that every question time there was more and more opportunity, and there was a surplus of material about which they could have been asked questions. It must have been an easy life for a journalist in the last nine years—so much to ask and so many questions to put to government ministers.

The failure of the Morrison government to bring in a national anticorruption commission was not just a failure of public policy; it was a monumental political blunder. We've seen mea culpas from those opposite. Again and again we've heard speeches all day from those opposite saying: 'We should have done it. If only we'd had another year to do it!' Seriously! And then I've heard speech after speech from those opposite, excoriating the bill that they're going to vote for. Seriously! Honestly, come into this place and be credible about what you're doing and what you're saying.

They're going through this bill with a fine toothcomb as if somehow they're born-again civil libertarians. What about the Australian building and corruption commission, as I would call it? Seriously, that ABCC is just an affront to civil liberties in this country. Those opposite couldn't care less about workers in the workplace and what they have to put up with or about passers-by who look at what happened on a worksite. Seriously, don't come in here and go through this bill with a legalistic fine toothcomb as if somehow there's some problem there. You spent nine years trashing civil liberties. Honestly! Seriously, you come in here and say: 'All of a sudden, we've had some Damascus road conversion experience and we've seen the light, brothers and sisters. We've seen the light.' Honestly! Seriously! The ABCC should go, and this this bill should pass.

Those opposite have got it wrong yet again. This was a huge issue in the campaign—a massive issue. And yet it's almost as if, when they went across from this side of the chamber to that side of the chamber, somehow their intelligence didn't go with them. It's quite astonishing. At an intellectual level they get it, but at a visceral level or an intuitive level they just cannot bring themselves to say, 'This is the right thing to do.' So they'll vote for this. We'll see, eventually, the Liberal and National party members grit their teeth. They'll hang onto their desks like this and they'll vote for it, but they don't want to. They just don't want to at all. We know that, and you can hear it in every sentence uttered, every word spoken and every paragraph that comes out of their mouths. They do not want to support this bill. They just do not. They will not. But they have to do it, because they know the public's view on this issue is so different from theirs.

It's not just those people sitting over there. There are Labor people sitting over here who won elections principally on this issue: trust, accountability and integrity in government. We announced this would be one of our first priorities, and I commend the Attorney-General for doing this. We first made this promise in 2018, and we committed to it in the 2019 election. I committed to it as a candidate, and in 2022 we made that commitment yet again in the election. We promised that, if elected, we would legislate a national anticorruption commission by the end of this year as one of our first priorities.

So these bills establish a strong, open, independent National Anti-Corruption Commission to investigate serious or systemic corrupt conduct across the entire federal public sector. It's built on a number of design principles, and I'll go through them, because it's necessary. On broad jurisdiction, the commission has broad powers to investigate serious or systemic corrupt behaviour or conduct across the Commonwealth public sector by ministers; parliamentarians and their staff; statutory office holders; employees of all government entities; and government contractors.

On the definition of corruption, Griffith University Professor of Public Policy and Law AJ Brown has noted that it is 'a definition that's simpler, more flexible, and less legalistic or complicated than most state definitions'.

The commission will operate independent of government, making its own decisions. It won't be dictated to. There won't be some totalitarian regime of the Left or Right which dictates to the commissioners what they do. They're independent. They'll make their own minds up. They will have the discretion to commence inquiries into serious or systemic corruption. They can take referrals, of course, with whistleblowers from the public being involved in that process as well. It shouldn't be people in this chamber or the other place who dictate to the NACC, because we don't live in a society where the powers of government are combined. We believe in the separation of powers. There was a Premier in my home state of Queensland who couldn't understand the separation of powers when asked questions about it in court. But we believe in it on this side of the chamber. We believe in the separation of powers. As someone who practised as a lawyer for nearly a quarter of a century, I strongly believe in the separation of powers. We shouldn't be determining who gets prosecuted or who gets before the NACC. The NACC should make those decisions and take referrals from whistleblowers in the public. So there are some good things here.

On oversight, there is a statutory parliamentary joint committee empowered to require the commission to provide information about its work. It will have people from the crossbench, the opposition and the government. We're familiar with this sort of concept in parliament, where there are people from all different political parties and Independents on parliamentary committees. I've heard statements from those opposite—even from some of the crossbenchers. If you've been in parliament as long as I have—the last 15 years—then you'll know there are good relationships. Sometimes the theatre of politics is on full display in question time, but, when you get into a parliamentary committee, people work together and take it seriously, constructively, cooperatively, collegiately. They work together because they know they've been entrusted by the public, by their states, by their electorates, to do the right thing by the country. They work together, and I have every faith that this parliamentary joint committee will do likewise.

The commission has retrospective powers, the ability to look into things from the past. I know those opposite don't like that concept. They give so much fodder, so much stuff, that could be looked at by the commission.

There will be public hearings. The commission has a power to hold public hearings in exceptional circumstances and where it is in the public interest to do so. There needs to be a broad discretion in that space. The threshold strikes the right balance, I think, with the benefits of a public hearing balanced against potential negative impacts. I've got to say this: I have seen people being treated unfairly and having their reputations trashed when crime and corruption commissions look into circumstances, and people have been emblazoned on the front pages of newspapers in public as if they have done something wrong, when they have simply given evidence before those commissions. So you've got to get the balance right. You can't be having people's reputations unfairly trashed when they're charged with nothing and found guilty of nothing. You've got to strike the right balance. I think this is the right way to go.

The commission has the power to make findings of fact, including findings of corrupt conduct, and to refer those things to the Australian Federal Police or the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions. The commission will have procedural fairness as a requirement, and its findings will be subject to judicial review.

On independence, it's good that senior people like the commissioners on the NACC will be term limited—no huge longevity on these things. If people stay on for decade after decade in those roles, they become less subject to parliamentary oversight, less accountable to the public. So term limiting people in the role of commissioners and deputy commissioners is absolutely the right thing to do.
There are strong protections for whistleblowers and exemptions for journalists to protect the identity of sources.

Shamefully—and I say 'shamefully' deliberately—we are the last jurisdiction to establish an anticorruption commission. If there is one salutary thing about this delay, it's that it has led us to look at some of the best elements of the state and territory models.

It's important that we commit resources to this project, and there's nearly $263 million over the forward estimates for this purpose. So this is not a body that's going to be without teeth. It will have resources. It will have strong jurisdiction. It will have the funding to do what it needs to do, with the staff, capabilities and capacity to take referrals and look at allegations. We welcome the ongoing work of integrity experts and fellow parliamentarians who have been involved in this process and who have examined how the commission will work. We've had a parliamentary inquiry look at it.

We've not been without corruption in this country. We've had coups and other activities—even back in colonial days, such as the Rum Corps in New South Wales. Most states have witnessed periods of official and police corruption. I'm from Queensland, and as fellow Queenslanders, Mr Speaker, we're pretty familiar with the corrosive effects of government and police corruption on public life, particularly during the Bjelke-Peterson regime. It took the Fitzgerald inquiry and the great reforming Labor government under Wayne Goss to clean it up. Then, again, in 2015 the Palaszczuk Labor government was elected on a platform of integrity and accountability, after Queenslanders got truly fed up with the lack of transparency of the LNP government led by Campbell Newman. We have seen some pretty egregious examples of corruption and graft at the local government level as well. Indeed, there have been people in my community who have been charged, and rightly so, and who have felt the full force of the law.

The voters were never credited with intelligence, in my view, and given the respect they deserved by the Morrison government. Promises were made and never delivered. Questions from journalists were treated as annoyances. Basic standards of accountability were pushed aside by the Morrison government. So this government, the Albanese Labor government, has got a big job to do. This is nation-building reform, in my view. It's nation building like you'd see in infrastructure. It is absolutely vital to restore integrity in government and integrity in democracy.

I'm very keen to see this legislation go through. I applaud those who have been involved in the Joint Select Committee on National Anti-Corruption Commission Legislation. I applaud Senator White and the member for Indi, who was her deputy, and the membership drawn from various parts of the House, for their unanimous report and their recommendations. It's really important that we continue that. The bill has been looked at by multiple inquiries, and that is very, very important.

I think the government has got it right. At the state level—and I've seen that in my area—there have been times when crime and corruption commissions haven't got the balance right. I've witnessed circumstances back in my home state where people were unfairly treated by crime and corruption commissions—circumstances where prosecutions were withdrawn, where people were found not guilty, where convictions were overturned on appeal and where councillors lost their jobs when having been found guilty of nothing. The balance needs to be there, the safeguards need to be there and the protections need to be there, and they are in this bill.

That's why our commitment to the Australian public and their vote at the last election have been fulfilled today. On this side of politics, the Albanese government heard the message. And we won't take lectures from the crossbenches in relation to this issue; it has been our policy for many, many years. We're delivering on that commitment. Our aim is to create a lasting body, one that lasts for not just this term of government but also the next one and the one after that. Integrity should be above partisan politics, and I'm pleased to support this legislation tonight.

Ms WATSON-BROWN (Ryan) (21:48): I know that the people in my electorate of Ryan are very concerned about integrity in politics and government. During my election campaign, time and again the people of Ryan raised integrity as a primary concern, and it wasn't hard to see why. In that campaign period, #OurDemocracy surveyed Australians about integrity, and the results from my electorate of Ryan were rather telling: 98 per cent supported a federal anticorruption body, 97 per cent supported caps on political donations, 100 per cent supported disclosure of who makes political donations, 93 per cent believed large political donations undermine our democracy, 93 per cent supported limits on election campaign spending, 98 per cent supported disclosure of professional lobbying of politicians and 100 per cent supported truth in political advertising laws—pretty convincing, Ryan. So I ran a forum about integrity. It was extremely well attended and it was abundantly clear from the nature of the questions and from the robust discussions what was of most concern to people. They said that a lot of Australian voters had disengaged from politics and suggested that may even have been an intended side-effect of the bad behaviour of MPs. There was curiosity about how integrity commissions had been operating in Australian states and questions about how it has taken so long for a federal body to be established. So many will be very happy that this process has commenced. Questions and concerns were raised about the relationship between our corporatised and monopolised media and the lessening of integrity in our politics.

There was debate about the extent of powers for an integrity commission and robust discussions about what people felt they should be and why, and this last point was the most-voiced concern. People felt very strongly that reform of political donation laws and cash-for-access issues were critical to restoring integrity in politics. They said that people had switched off because they were not being listened to. The abiding sentiment was expressed like this: elected officials are meant to represent us but too often they seem to represent major corporations, and some of those corporations are outright harmful with deep pockets, like fossil fuel companies, banks, large developers et cetera, who are setting the policy agenda in Australia. They said their profit motives gazump our wellbeing and they exercise undue control over our government. Furthermore, they said many of the channels through which corporate power exerts influence are informal and hidden.

The loud and clear message was that this is seriously undermining political integrity and, indeed, our democracy. People desperately wanted integrity legislation and they wanted it to address this fundamental issue or, they believed, it would not do the job of cleaning up politics. So now, here we are with the new government and a new parliament of quite a different complexion because many wanted that change, and definitely a big part of that was about integrity.

In a welcome and very much overdue development, we have before us this National Anti-Corruption Commission bill. The Attorney-General says it will create a commission with jurisdiction to investigate public sector corruption as well as—and these are the aspects I want to focus on—prevention and education functions to bolster anticorruption efforts in the Commonwealth public sector. This is an important first step. It is important because true integrity and real scrutiny are absolutely fundamental to the fair operation of our democracy and to putting the interests of everyday people, not the interests of politicians and lobbyists, at the heart of what we do. That is why we Greens on the crossbench have been advocating for a long time for integrity legislation that works. In fact, Senator Larissa Waters introduced a federal ICAC bill in 2019 which was passed by the Senate but rejected by the House. This current bill is a promising first step towards fixing our democracy, and we Greens are pleased to be working with the government to improve many aspects of it.

But some important questions remain. The Attorney-General says the NACC will be able to investigate the conduct of public officials and those who seek to corrupt public officials. This includes power to investigate ministers, parliamentarians and their staff, statutory office holders, employees and contractors of government agencies and contracted service providers, but what about other groups who exercise undue influence? How can the independence of the NACC be guaranteed while former politicians can be appointed as commissioners? How can transparency really be achieved when the bar for public hearings is so high? And how will whistleblowers be protected? The recent budget contained a commitment of $262 million to the NACC over four years but there is no independent budget process in place, meaning this could be significantly reduced by any future government at will. How can we guarantee this body isn't intentionally hobbled by future governments?

A much broader concern hangs over all discussions around the Anti-Corruption Commission and is perhaps the biggest issue facing our democracy. What is the issue? It is that corporate influence can still buy political outcomes to the detriment of ordinary Australians. So just as with climate action and disaster response, any integrity and anticorruption legislation and commission should be designed to address prevention and mitigation, not just cleaning up after the fact, which, I believe, is the limited remit of this new legislation.

To achieve that prevention and that mitigation of corruption, we need structural, systemic change to the way Australian politics currently operates. This means putting caps on political donations and ending corporate donations to political parties. Unlike Labor and the coalition, who've taken over $230 million in corporate donations over the last 10 years, we Greens don't take corporate money. We strongly believe that it's corrupting the true representation of ordinary Australians.

Structural and systemic change means stopping cash for access meetings. It's, frankly, absurd that we allow a corporation to spend $27½ thousand to attend a special business luncheon with a minister and still call ourselves a democracy. This change means disclosure of who makes political donations. It means disclosure of professional lobbying of politicians. It means putting a doorstop in the revolving door of lobbyists with the ear of government, including ex-politicians who land plush jobs in lobbying companies and then reappear in government or on influential boards in an endless rinse-and-repeat cycle. It means taking corporate interests out of our essential services and bringing them back into public ownership so we can have proper public scrutiny over decisions that affect our lives, rather than allowing corporate boards to make these decisions for us.

As the people of my electorate of Ryan have said to me, 'Democracy should not be for sale to the highest bidders'. It's time to legislate an anticorruption commission. It's time politicians, ministers and government officials are held to account for corruption and misconduct. We Greens are negotiating for more-robust possible legislation here. But let's not think it stops here—job's done, democracy fixed—because even if this NACC goes through it will still be entirely legal for the Labor and Liberal Party to take donations of, say, $100,000 from gas giant Santos, in the same year that their government is signing off on environmental approvals for a new gas project. It'll still be legal for Santos to buy special access to a minister in that same year. So, let's get moving on anticorruption, but let's also get serious about corporate power in this country.

Ms ROBERTS (Pearce) (21:56): I stand here as a proud member of the Albanese Labor government, which strongly believes in the importance of integrity to underpin everything we do as a government. Every decision we make here should be through the lens of integrity. This National Anti-Corruption Commission Bill 2022 will absolutely achieve that. It is a powerful anticorruption instrument that will deliver the single biggest integrity reform that this parliament has seen in decades, something that I and many others welcome wholeheartedly.

This bill is about restoring integrity to government and its processes. The Albanese government is committed to strengthening this framework to improve standards of integrity across the public sector. It is about restoring the faith and trust that members of our community, the Australian people, have placed in us as decision-makers. We must lead by example. Its design principles were developed with some of Australia's leading integrity advocates.

I know that this bill is important to my electorate in Perth, Western Australia. I know that because on 21 May 2022 the people of Pearce clearly voted strongly for integrity. It was a regular, consistent point of discussion during the campaign. The community voted for honesty, for accountability and for transparency in government. They demanded that it was time to strengthen standards of integrity in our federal government.
This bill includes the best elements of state and territory anticorruption commissions and laws. It uses benchmarks and processes to improve our standards and to lift our game.

I would like to highlight the many different integrity standards that local, state and federal members are held to. I served my community as a councillor and mayor in one of the largest and fastest growing local governments in Australia over a period of more than two decades. In my time as a councillor, and popularly elected mayor, I ensured that the way I conducted myself was aligned with the Local Government Act, in addition to what the public and my community expected of an elected official. I am here to serve my community. I am here to serve them well and with transparency. In my first speech to parliament I promised to serve with all the passion, prudence, integrity, energy and resolve that I possess. It is important that every public official be held to a high standard of integrity.

Australians demand and expect honest and hardworking representatives who make decisions in the community's best interest. This bill ensures that those in positions of power in government are held to account as they must be. This bill is delivering what people in my electorate of Pearce and constituents right across our nation require and deserve: transparency, honesty and good governance. It delivers on an Albanese Labor government's election commitment to legislate a powerful, transparent and independent National Anti-Corruption Commission.

This bill provides the commission with the powers to investigate serious or systemic corrupt conduct across the Commonwealth public sector. The commission will have the power to investigate criminal and non-criminal corrupt conduct occurring before or after its establishment. The commission will form part of Australia's broader integrity framework, and my electorate of Pearce supports broader integrity. The independent commission will have the authority to investigate ministers, parliamentarians and their staff, statutory officeholders, employees of all government entities and government contractors. My electorate, along with the rest of the Australian people, demand this sort of accountability.

This bill is delivering something that had not been addressed by the former government. Given that the community in my electorate of Pearce resoundingly voted for integrity at the May federal election, I know that this bill will meet their understandably high expectations of each and every one of us here in this place. So I would like to highlight some important elements of this bill. The commission will have a full suite of powers similar to those of a royal commission. The commissioner will be empowered to undertake investigations into a corruption issue if they are of the opinion that it could involve serious or systemic corrupt conduct. Importantly, there will be transparency in the reporting at the conclusion of investigations. The commission will be required to produce a report containing findings and recommendations. Where a public hearing has been held, a report will be tabled in parliament. Other reports will be published by the commissioner where that is in the public interest. This reporting requirement will also serve to educate the public and act as a deterrent for corrupt behaviour.

This work will be informed by the insights the commission draws from investigations and the intelligence it collects about corruption. Understandably, education can be key to awareness and creating change. Education can empower people to speak up. The educational remit of the commission will help change behaviours by allowing the public to learn about what the commission does and how it functions. The commission will also conduct broader public education about the risks of corruption and promote the methods people can use to report corrupt conduct. This education function will enable members of the public to understand how they can play a crucial role in stamping out corruption. We need to see people call it out in an honest and transparent manner and to feel safe to report corrupt behaviour and to bring it to the attention of those who conduct the investigation. I strongly believe that this aspect of education and prevention will be welcome nationwide. This bill is well researched and measured. It ensures transparency, as well as transparency in its oversight. The commission will be overseen by a parliamentary joint committee and an inspector. That joint committee will have 12 members—three government, two opposition and one crossbench member from each house, including a government chair with a casting vote.

The bill includes strong protection for whistleblowers against adverse consequences, including criminal offences and immunities. Public officials making disclosures to the commission will also be protected under the Public Interest Disclosure Act. What is important is that there is procedural fairness and many other safeguards in this bill. That includes the provision for the commissioner to release public statements to clarify the status of those appearing as witnesses and to make findings that a person has not engaged in corrupt conduct to avoid undue reputational damage. Procedural fairness is included for individuals or agencies who are to be the subject of an adverse finding or opinion, as well as the ability for them to seek judicial review of findings. These safeguards are put in place to protect reputations and protect livelihoods.

This bill ensures that there are also appropriate protections for journalists. Those protections include an exemption from answering questions or providing information that would enable the identity of a source to be ascertained.

I also speak in support of the amendments tabled today to further strengthen this already strong and necessary bill. We are listening intently to feedback with a willingness to work with the opposition and stakeholders. We are working to ensure the National Anti-Corruption Commission is effective and will be able to achieve its very important goals.

The government has committed substantial funding of $262 million over four years for the establishment and ongoing operation of the commission. This funding will ensure the commission has the staff, the capabilities and the capacity to triage all referrals and allegations it receives. It will also conduct timely investigations and undertake corruption prevention and educational activities.

Every person on this side of the House is on the same page—supportive, collaborative, engaging and committed to doing the right thing by their communities and by the nation. This bill is something we should all be very proud of.

I congratulate the Attorney-General for his diligence and commitment. To all involved in the formulation of this bill, including the Joint Select Committee on National Anti-Corruption Commission Legislation, I say a very sincere thank you on behalf of my community. I thank them also for their significant consultation with government departments and key agencies. In conclusion, as mentioned earlier, constituents voted for integrity and transparency at the May 2022 federal election and this government, the Albanese Labor government, will deliver those important principles. This bill is long overdue and is a clear reflection of how we are now getting on with the job and putting in place the framework to ensure that corruption has no place in this parliament.
Mr Gorman: I require the debate to be adjourned.
The SPEAKER: The debate is adjourned, and resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
NOTICES
Ms Rishworth to make a statement on Wednesday, 23 November 2022 on the following significant matter—International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women.

Mr Jones to present a Bill for an Act to amend the law relating to corporations, consumer credit and other matters in the Treasury portfolio, to make miscellaneous and technical amendments of the law of the Commonwealth, and for related purposes. (Treasury Laws Amendment (Modernising Business Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2022)
Mr Burke to move:

That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the following from occurring in relation to proceedings on the National Anti-Corruption Commission Bill 2022 and the National Anti-Corruption Commission (Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2022:

(1) notwithstanding standing order 31, if the second reading debate has not concluded earlier, at 8 pm on Wednesday, 23 November, the bills being called on together for further consideration, with the second reading debate continuing until either:
(a) no further Members rise to speak; or
(b) a Minister requires that the debate be adjourned at no earlier than 10 pm;
at which point, debate being adjourned and the House immediately adjourning until Thursday, 24 November at 9 am;
(2) from 7.30 pm on Wednesday, 23 November until the adjournment of the House:
(a) any division called for being deferred until the first opportunity on Thursday, 24 November; and

(b) if any Member draws the attention of the Speaker to the state of the House, the Speaker announcing that he will count the House at the first opportunity on Thursday, 24 November, if the Member then so desires; and
(3) any variation to this arrangement being made only on a motion moved by a Minister.

Ms
Ryan to move:
That this House:
(1) notes that in May 2022, Australians voted for change and for a Labor Government to build a better future;
(2) further notes that in the six months since the election, the Parliament:
(a) has already legislated to:
(i) fix the mess the previous Government made of the aged care sector;
(ii) deliver a cleaner and greener future to tackle climate change;
(iii) deliver cheaper medicines;
(iv) ten days paid family and domestic violence leave;
(v) repeal the cashless debit card;
(vi) expand access to the Commonwealth Seniors Health Card; and
(vii) deliver a 'Future Made in Australia' with Jobs and Skills Australia; and
(b) is currently debating legislation to deliver:
(i) secure jobs and better pay;
(ii) a national anti-corruption commission;
(iii) safer and secure workplaces for Australian women; and
(iv) cheaper childcare for Australian families; and
(3) acknowledges that the Government is:
(a) delivering on its election commitments to build a better future; and
(b) being a responsible government in the face of challenging times globally.
Ms Byrnes to move:
That this House:
(1) acknowledges that the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) can be life-changing for Australians with disability;
(2) recognises the NDIS is not working as effectively as it should due to a decade of neglect and mismanagement by the previous Government, creating an urgent need to:
(a) improve outcomes for participants;
(b) restore trust in the scheme and certainty for participants and their families; and
(c) improve the effectiveness and sustainability of the NDIS and broader social and economic benefits, without imposing the types of blunt force cuts favoured by the previous Government;
(3) notes the measures the Government has already taken to get the NDIS back on track, including:
(a) installing new leadership at the National Disability Insurance Agency (NDIA) and putting people with a disability at the centre of the scheme;
(b) reducing the inherited 4,500 case backlog of expensive, time-consuming appeals before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal by 2000 cases to date;
(c) reducing the number of people with disability trapped in hospitals despite being medically fit for discharge; and
(d) funding 380 new positions in the NDIA for better and faster planning decisions for people with disability and their families, carers, disability service providers and workers;
(4) calls on Members of the House to support the work ahead to make the NDIS the world-leading scheme it was designed to be, through:
(a) the root and branch review of the NDIS to improve its effectiveness, so that future generations receive the benefits of the scheme;
(b) planning for a workforce that can support the projected increase in NDIS participants;
(c) establishing a senior executive role within the NDIA to bolster its stewardship of the sector; and
(d) reducing waste and fraud so money intended for participants is not syphoned off or squandered; and
(5) further notes the benefits to the Australian community and our economy when we invest in people with disability and break down barriers to their participation in social and economic life.
Ms Steggall to present a Bill for an Act to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, and for related purposes. (Commonwealth Electoral Amendment (Stop the Lies) Bill 2022)
Mr Ted O'Brien to move:
That this House:
(1) notes that:
(a) the Government has committed Australia to the United Nations' 'loss and damage' fund without providing any details on what it will cost Australians or how it will be implemented;
(b) the Government has signed an international agreement which could cost Australians tens of billions of dollars without outlining any plan as to what is expected of Australia;
(c) the 'loss and damage' fund is reported to cost upwards of US $2 trillion globally per year by 2030;
(d) China, the world's second largest economy and the world's biggest carbon emitter has not been ruled out as a potential recipient of compensation funding due to its status as a developing nation;
(e) this scheme will penalise Australia for being blessed with an abundance of energy resources—resources that have been used to lift hundreds of millions of people out of absolute poverty;

(f) the Prime Minister was quick to rule out support for Australian families struggling with cost-of-living pressures in the budget but has effectively signed a blank cheque (which could be worth tens of billions of dollars) for an international compensation scheme with no detail, and for which no economic modelling has been undertaken;

(g) Australia has a long history of supporting its regional partners, especially those in the Pacific, and at COP26 the former Government doubled its climate finance commitment to $2 billion over 2020-25, with at least $700 million for Pacific climate and disaster finance; and

(h) instead of finding a solution to skyrocketing domestic power prices, that are threatening up to 800,000 manufacturing jobs, the Minister for Climate Change and Energy has focused the Government's attention on committing the country to international pledges for which there is no detail; and
(2) calls on the Government to explain what the 'loss and damage' fund will cost Australian taxpayers.
Dr Gillespi e to move:
That this House:
(1) notes that, the:

(a) Restart Investment to Sustain and Expand (RISE) fund was an effective and targeted arts funding initiative supporting 541 projects in over 4,000 locations, creating over 195,000 job opportunities and experiences reaching more than 55 million Australians;

(b) Arts Sustainability Fund was key to supporting systemically significant arts companies to survive through the COVID-19 pandemic with recipients including, the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra, the Sydney Theatre Company, Brandenburg Ensemble, Queensland Ballet, Opera Australia, Design Tasmania, the National Institute of Dramatic Art, Melbourne Theatre Company, The Australian Ballet, Belvoir Theatre, Circa Contemporary Circus Limited, and Malthouse Theatre; and
(c) highest level of Commonwealth arts funding ever achieved was under the previous Government in 2021-2022 when the funding exceeded $1 billion; and
(2) expresses its regret at the adverse effect on the arts sector of politically motivated arts policy decisions since May 2022 including, the:

(a) grave mishandling of the additional $20 million of funding for RISE which was provided in the March 2022 budget, with the Government delaying action for many months before cancelling this funding in October;

(b) announcement in September that the Government would establish a Live Performance Support Fund with no guidelines, eligibility conditions or other details provided at that time and still not provided two months later; and
(c) abrupt and discourteous disbanding of the Creative Economy Taskforce which comprised a distinguished group of arts leaders doing outstanding work in advising on the Government arts policy.
Mr Boyce to move:
That this House:
(1) acknowledges that Australian households are worried about increasing pressures from the cost-of-living crisis brought about by recent interest rate rises and continued inflation;
(2) notes that:
(a) consecutive interest rate rises since May 2022 have placed mortgage stresses on many Australian households and more rises are expected;
(b) Australians are hurting, but in its budget, the Government failed to outline a plan to take pressure off interest rates; and
(c) Australians cannot wait another seven months for the Government's second budget to come up with a plan to deal with cost-of-living pressures that have become very real and painful for so many;

(3) recognises that despite telling Australians their power bills are going up by more than 50 per cent, their mortgage payments will continue to rise, the cost of groceries will remain high, and inflation will continue to surge, the Government still has no plan to tackle this cost-of-living crisis; and
(4) calls on the Government to focus on the issues that matter to Australians and to deliver a real and comprehensive plan to ease inflation and cost-of-living pressures.

Ms Tink to present a Bill for an Act to amend the law relating to fuel quality standards and road vehicle standards, and for related purposes. (Fuel and Vehicle Standards Legislation Amendment (Reducing Vehicle Pollution) Bill 2022)
Mr B rian Mitchell to move:
That this House:
(1) notes that:

(a) for nearly a decade, the former Government's oversight of the National Broadband Network (NBN) had been a masterclass in technological incompetence and financial mismanagement, causing Australia to trail other developed countries on broadband quality and speeds;

(b) the Government is delivering what Australians voted for and will expand full fibre access to 1.5 million premises by 2025 with a $2.4 billion equity investment over four years in the 2022-23 budget;
(c) this will:
(i) deliver a faster and more reliable NBN to more families, communities, and businesses and allow more Australians to take advantage of an increasingly digital global economy; and

(ii) give Australians who now rely on copper connections the choice of having full fibre connections to their premises if they want a faster NBN service than their current copper wire can deliver; and

(2) acknowledges economic analysis commissioned by NBN Co that estimates the additional fibre-to-the-premises connections will deliver an additional $20 billion uplift in gross domestic product by 2030 through connecting communities and businesses to faster and more reliable broadband services.
Mr Chandler-Mather to move:
That this House:
(1) notes that:
(a) Vanuatu's Minister of Climate Change, Ralph Regenvanu, would only back Australia's bid to host the 2026 COP if Australia does not commit to any new coal or gas handouts; and
(b) the Government's first budget has over $40 billion in fossil fuel subsidies including $1.9 billion to open up a new LNG terminal and petrochemical hub in Darwin Harbour; and
(2) calls on the Government to end fossil fuel subsidies.

Mr Wilkie to present a Bill for an Act to amend the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995, and for related purposes. (Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Amendment (Loot Boxes) Bill 2022)

The DEPUTY SPEAKER ( Mr Wilkie )
took the chair at 12:30.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER ( Mr Wilkie )
took the chair at 12:30.
CONSTITUENCY STATEMENTS
Youth Voice in Parliament Week

Ms
SHARKIE (Mayo) (12:30): Earlier this year, Foundations for Tomorrow sent me their Awareness to action report, which captured over 10,000 young Australian voices, providing an insight into critical issues for young people. The results of the report are confronting. Only four per cent of young Australians have absolute confidence in our approach to solving global challenges, with 60 per cent feeling uncertain about the future. When young people were asked what traits would enable them to put their trust in leaders they identified proactive action, increased sustainability and improved transparency. While these findings indicate a trust deficit amongst young Australians, they also provide insight into how the situation may be rectified. Our young voices are diverse and perceptive. It's time they were heard.

Many Australians, especially young people, remain underrepresented in our parliament, and I believe that until they see themselves in our chambers we will struggle to rebuild this trust. This group embodies the future of Australia. It is our responsibility to encourage their engagement and their shaping of it.

To achieve this goal I joined with the Raise Our Voice campaign, which strives to amplify young voices, offering a platform on which to lead conversations on domestic and foreign policy. This year participants were asked to submit a 90-second speech in response to the question 'What should Australia's new parliament accomplish?' In Mayo I received five distinctive entries, and I felt that each warranted recognition. Fifteen-year-old Addison discussed sexual assault, identifying failures in our justice system and the need for greater action. Eleven-year-old Denver argued convincingly for the construction of an Adelaide cricket ground. Seventeen-year-old Thomas spoke of a future in which 'issues of oppression and coercion are brought into the spotlight', with similar views being presented by 11-year-old Hudson, who spoke about 'increasing awareness of racism' and 'remembering that we're all humans, no matter what race you are'. Finally, 16 year old Daniel shared and excerpt from his poem about climate action. He wrote:
I gaze with sorrow,
For I know what comes tomorrow.
Water, wind and fire
of which she warned them would follow.

I must say, it is a privilege to talk and engage with young people in our community. I don't know about other members in this chamber, but certainly when I talk to young people in my community I feel immense hope for tomorrow.
Youth Voice in Parliament Week

Mr LAXALE (Bennelong) (12:33): I too am reading a few statements from young people within my electorate, on behalf of Raise Our Voice Australia. Its aim is to amplify diverse young voices 'to actively lead conversations in politics, domestic and foreign policy'. The first one is from Yuna Cho, who is a 14-year-old student from the Bennelong electorate:
I am one of the many lucky people living in this country being able to proudly call myself Australian despite my foreign heritage.
People from all around the globe are able to call Australia their home, and despite our accepting society, it would be an overstatement to say that everyone in our country is treated equally.
Racial prejudice is still apparent in our society.
Our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people still have to deal with racism, and our migrants and refugees still fear their contribution to our larger community.
Australia is a socially developed country when it comes to multicultural diversity.
However, we can still achieve more. I wish to see Australia as a unified, patriotic nation.
I wish for our new Australian parliament to proudly represent our nation to become stronger and a more harmonious nation.
Every single Australian should be proud of our beautiful land, our people, our cultures, and our differences which makes us all unique yet unified at the same time.
The leaders of our country should show us what it means to be an Australian, and represent our country with pride.
I hope our new Australian parliament will help us build the country we all love.
The second speech is from Patrick, who is 19, works full time and lives in Bennelong:

Housing in this country is broken. Young people like myself are going to auctions only to find themselves outbid by someone who already owns two, three or four houses, meanwhile pushing up the price of housing and making it harder for young people like myself to enter the market.
Why is this happening?

A good place for the new parliament to start would be by examining the merits behind giving public money to people who are fortunate enough to already own multiple houses and using it as a tax dodge to write off the loss should they choose to invest by buying up further supply in the housing market.
As a result—the cost of rent and property values goes up and up and up, and one of the key things the new parliament could do would be to invest in nation building projects like public housing.

If we invested in public housing, we would not only create thousands of new jobs and opportunities for young people through apprenticeships, we would also help reduce inequality and crucially, bring down rates for everyone else …

It gives me great pleasure to read these two speeches on behalf of young people in my electorate. I encourage as many young people as possible to be engaged in politics and to reach out to their MPs. Maybe they too can have a speech read out here in parliament on their behalf. We don't necessarily have to agree with everyone, but a conversation is incredibly important. I thank Patrick and Yuna for their contribution in this parliament.
Youth Voice in Parliament Week

Ms PRICE (Durack—Opposition Whip) (12:35): It's a privilege to stand here during Youth Voice in Parliament Week to present a speech written by 14-year-old Joshua Patrick from Northam, which is in the great electorate of Durack. I was very impressed by Joshua's understanding of some of the key issues affecting regional and remote Western Australia. I truly appreciate the effort that he has gone to to ensure that his experience is heard. This is what Joshua wrote:

Having personally had lived experience, or had those in my immediate family experience disability; caring role and accompanying poverty; complex medical issues and unnecessary health system battles; the inherent isolation and diminished opportunities for those living in regional (and remote) WA; and domestic violence and sexual abuse, I am well-placed to comment on what the new Parliament should achieve. I am also a passionate, creative experimenter in the realm of affordable, achievable, sustainable environmental practices and solutions.
The recommendations I would prioritise, are:
A more flexible, long-term/future-proofing and individualised approach to disability funding disbursement

An increase in the Carer's Pension for families who find themselves suddenly thrust into a caring role where the sole or primary breadwinner must necessarily immediately cease work, with a fraction of the income required to cover fundamental living expenses plus additional medical expenses/travel/parking etc.
Greater holistic support services such as treatment options and in-home care for those suffering chronic or complex health conditions and their families/carers

A greater range of educational and recreational opportunities for young people living in remote or regional WA to provide equal chances for those equally as gifted as their metropolitan counterparts to succeed academically, as well as equal opportunities for geographically disadvantaged young people to excel in the sporting arena
More prompt validation and action when victims of domestic violence, particularly vulnerable children and single mothers, disclose or give cause to suspect domestic violence or abuse

Continued and increased support for schemes to encourage and provide resources for young people with the intelligence, passion, drive, energy, opportunity and creativity to come up with solutions, suggestions or proposals that may prompt society to stop living so unsustainably, whether large- or smaller-scale ideas, such as the Water Corporation's 'Think Tank Challenge', (in which I am a finalist)

I hope you will see that I am well-placed to make the above recommendations knowledgeably and from a position of rare and unique insight, due to the diverse range of life circumstances I have personally experienced in my life.
That's the end of Joshua's speech. Thank you, Joshua, very much, for your incredibly thoughtful contribution. I look forward to meeting you soon in Northam to discuss your priorities further.
Queensland: Floods

Mr PERRETT (Moreton) (12:38): I was very pleased last week to learn that up to 10 local sporting community clubs in my electorate will share a total of $5,498,083 to assist with flood recovery. Last week, the Australian and Queensland governments announced that 200 sites across 20 local government areas are set to benefit from $75 million in joint Australian and Queensland government funding in response to the major flooding and severe rainfall that have occurred since late 2021.

I know that local state members Mark Bailey, the member for Miller; Peter Russo, the member for Toohey; and Jess Pugh, the member for Mount Ommaney, were also pleased to hear this good news. As elected representatives, we know how important local sporting clubs are for our communities. Local clubs provide enormous social benefits. Most of them provide a fair, safe and inclusive environment for children and young adults to have an enjoyable and healthy sporting experience. Sport has enormous health and social benefits. It helps children keep fit. It teaches children the importance of teamwork and of winning and losing. Anyone who wants a game gets a go.

The best thing is that these funds will mean that clubs will be repaired, rebuilt and strengthened through the Community and Recreational Assets Recovery and Resilience Program and the Sport and Recreation Recovery Grant Program. Both programs are funded under the Disaster Recovery Funding Arrangements. This funding will help my local clubs re-establish operations and better cope with future severe weather. Many clubs like Brothers Saint Brendan's in Rocklea and the South Brisbane District Cricket Club were hit badly by the floods in 2011, and had to rebuild. They were then gutted again when it rained in February this year. These clubhouses, change rooms, playing fields and other important community assets are fundamental to volunteers delivering sport and active recreation opportunities in my community.

Congratulations to the Sherwood Magpies, the Brisbane Rugby League Referees Association, Queensland Gaelic Football, South Brisbane District Cricket Club, Western Districts Netball, Corinda Horse and Pony Club, Brothers Saint Brendan's, AFL Queensland, Oxley Rowing Club and the Carrington Boating Club Corinda, for each securing much-needed funding. I know our clubs are grateful for the funding. Many of them have already emailed my office. Many of them have limited means to fundraise for the money needed for the damage from the floods and rain, so these funds being distributed will be a great help. These projects will, obviously, also create jobs for local contractors, whose work will directly support their communities. Funds from these joint Commonwealth and state grants will help our clubs get back on their feet and better cope with the future severe weather events that we know are coming more and more often.
I, along with the state members, look forward to seeing these projects completed and seeing the Moreton clubs back up and running and better protected.

subdebateinfo.title: International Men's Day, Mackay Man of the Year, Shed Happens

p.span: International Men's Day
Mackay Man of the Year
Shed Happens

Mr WILLCOX (Dawson) (12:41): Saturday 19 November was International Men's Day—an important day to recognise the valuable contribution and the fundamental role that men play in society. It also gives us a chance to teach our young up-and-coming men about the importance of treating women with dignity and respect, to mentor them and to let them be the best men they can possibly be. On Friday 18 November, an event was hosted at Ocean International Resort, where over 120 people—men, women and our youths—came and had a fantastic morning.

It coincided with our 2022 Mackay Man of the Year award. I'm pleased to announce that Keiran Horsfall was successful in becoming Mackay Man of the Year. He is a senior constable in the Queensland police force—one of Queensland's finest—but he's also a father, a husband, and a mentor to many of Mackay's youth. He does an amazing job mentoring these young folk almost every day. He's instrumental in Project Booyah, in which he sits down with some of these young men who have got themselves on the wrong side of the tracks, has a discussion with them and brings them right back. I'm proud to say that, at the breakfast, there was a young man there who had a bit of a sketchy past, but Keiran's help brought him back on track and he has now got gainful employment and is actually going very, very well. There were also two runners-up: Col Benson and Bill Lansbury. Col is a retired serviceman. He looks after the Air Force memorial at Bakers Creek and can always be found at events such as Remembrance Day and Anzac Day, where he is constantly helping the community. Bill Lansbury is a husband, a father and a long-time Rotarian and is involved in many charities throughout Mackay.

Frank Cowell organised this event, with his committee: Councillor Fran Mann, Councillor Belinda Hassan and ex-CEO of RACQ CQ Rescue Ian Rowan. Frank is also Mackay's Citizen of the Year. He's instrumental in Shed Happens. Shed Happens is where people can go and have a cup of coffee, sit down and talk about blokes' issues. So well done to Frank.

Blokes, on average, make up seven out of nine suicides in Australia, and that is just an unforgiving statistic. We need to look after our men. We need to look after our boys. Well done, Frank Cowell and your team.
